title: Wednesday, 2nd December, 2015

11:11 am
PM

Snap bit of grey on the euro inflation figures

PM

Which clear the way for Draghi

PM

According to Eurostat’s flash estimate, HICP inflation remained stable in November at 0.1% year-on-year, below the consensus expectation for a 0.2% year-on-year increase in consumer prices. The low oil price continues to exert downward pressure on headline inflation, with the energy component falling 7.3% year-on-year. This impact is likely to soften a bit in the coming months on the back of a less favorable base effect.

The bigger surprise was the fall in core inflation to 0.9% year-on-year from 1.1% in October. While this figure has showed some volatility lately, it basically continues to hover around 1% (this would also correspond with headline inflation, once the oil price stabilizes), which is way below the ECB’s inflation target for a headline inflation below but close to 2.0%. Although consumption has picked up over the last quarters, benefitting especially the services sector, this hasn’t reflected yet in services price inflation. Somewhat unexpectedly services prices increased only 1.1% year-on-year, a deceleration from the 1.3% increase seen in October. This clearly reflects Mario Draghi’s worry that core inflation rates remain stubbornly low.

11:11 am
PM

This was the last important data release before the ECB’s meeting of the Governing Council tomorrow. And if anything, the figures give the doves within the Council the ammunition to go for the full Monty. Indeed, caution in further easing measures, disappointing market expectations, could cause the euro to strengthen and bond yields to rise, thereby implying unwarranted tightening of monetary conditions. We expect the ECB to cut the deposit rate by at least 15 Bp tomorrow, extend both in size (increase of monthly purchases by about €10 Bn), scope (broadening to regional debt) and duration (extending it at least to January 2017) its asset purchase program. A not yet anticipated refi rate cut to 0% might be the icing on the cake.

PM

Peter Vanden Houte -- ING

PM

And a snap from Capital Economics

11:12 am
PM

November’s weaker-than-expected euro-zone consumer prices figures give a final green light for the ECB to both increase the pace of its asset purchases and cut its deposit rate at tomorrow’s policy meeting. The unchanged headline rate of +0.1% is a downside surprise given both the country data already released and the fact that energy inflation was always likely to rise on the anniversary of a big drop in oil prices November last year. In the event, this was offset by a slight fall in food inflation and, more notably, a drop in core (ex food & energy) inflation from October’s +1.1% to +0.9%. The latter reflected falls in both core goods and services inflation.

Note that the headline inflation rate will rise quite sharply in the next few months on the anniversary of more big falls in oil prices. By January, it may be over 1.0%. But energy effects could turn negative again after that, while the slack in the economy is likely to continue to keep core price pressures contained. As such, the ECB is likely to remain nervous that a further prolonged period of below-target inflation will lead to a bigger drop in inflation expectations and take action tomorrow accordingly.

PM

Jonathan Loynes
Chief European Economist

PM

Footsie up 34 points currently

Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 4,775, up 139 (+3.00%), High: 4,775, Low: 4,665, Volume: 244.71k

AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,613, up 97 (+2.15%), High: 4,622, Low: 4,555, Volume: 796.18k

PM

11:14 am
BE

Couple of places, firstly a Morgan Stanley note.

BE

Year-start preview. They're shop to AstraZeneca

BE

And double-upgrade AstraZeneca.

11:14 am
BE

Here's the cover page.

BE

Retain In-Line industry view as US pricing, EM volatility and possible US rates hikes offset supportive M&A and pipelines. At a 13% P/E premium to market Pharma is fairly priced given its relative growth prospects. Prefer AstraZeneca, Novo, Roche in large pharma; Actelion, UCB in specialty pharma.
We keep our In-Line view on EU Pharma. The sector has outperformed EU MSCI by 7% over the last 12 months and now trades at a 13% P/E premium, close to its historical average of 11%. Consistent with our strategists, we believe this is fairly valued in the context of the sector's 2016-19 CAGR of 4% for sales and 10% for EPS and yields not better than the rest of the market (3% dividend, 5% FCF). Our 9% weighted average upside for the sector is close to our strategists' MSCI Europe 11% upside target for 2016. Also, possible US rates hikes in 2016 could cap sector outperformance as has been the case historically.

BE

US pricing pressure and EM volatility offset supportive M&A and pipelines. Increasing cost containment measures set up by payers (PBMs already impact primary care (respiratory, diabetes) and could expand to some specialty care segments. Pharma M&A is likely to stay active, though recent political changes in the US could deter US companies from pure tax optimization approaches and lead to a more regular stream of pipeline and restructuring deals.
EU Large Pharma: We are buyers of AstraZeneca, Novo Nordisk, Roche, and sellers of Bayer. We double upgrade AstraZeneca to OW (strategy playing out now, consensus EPS derisked), now a top pick with Novo Nordisk (attractive PEG, dense pipeline newsflow) and Roche (earnings visibility, pipeline upside). We neutralize Sanofi (M&A upside but timing uncertain) to EW and believe it is too early to come back on Novartis (high consensus expectations on Entresto, Glivec generic impact) and GSK (dividend and turnaround appeals unchanged). We keep Bayer at UW as limited optionality and low visibility on long-term pharma should block outperformance.
EU Specialty Pharma: We are buyers of Actelion, UCB and sellers of Merck KGaA. We prefer Actelion (strong operational execution) and UCB (pipeline upside). We neutralize Ipsen to EW (limited incremental upside) and keep UW on Merck KGaA (margin pressure to offset short term and risky pipeline upside).

11:15 am
BE

And on AstraZeneca specifically ............

BE

We expect AstraZeneca to reap the benefit of the strategic changes implemented by CEO Soriot three years ago. There are numerous pipeline catalysts in 2016 and a floor EPS of $4.20 looks plausible to us. Our favoured UK name - double upgrade to Overweight.
Inflexion point, double upgrade to OW. Our bear case (underappreciated risks on some growth platforms, pipeline overexcitement) seems to have largely played out with c 10% relative underperformance YTD and a 10% P/E discount to peers. After years of heavy investments, we see good pipeline optionality vs more reasonable consensus expectations ($13bn peak sales, previously $16bn). We see upside risk to FY16/17 consensus, which ignores AstraZeneca levers to reach its floor $4.20 core EPS despite patent expiries (growth platforms / launches on existing infrastructure with material savings, externalisation revenue). Rolling our 3-year CAGR EPS to 2019 captures the profitability inflexion point and allows for 10%+ growth.
Major R&D catalysts in FY16 (up to 600p/sh) before IO upside in 2017. AstraZeneca's refocused R&D strategy should bear fruit in 2016 with P3 read outs for 3 major assets (Brilinta, benralizumab and lynparza) and 3 new launches (Tagrisso, PT003, ZS9). We estimate up to $9bn combined opportunity (vs MSe $6bn and cons. c $5bn) implying up to 600p/sh NPV (c 10% EPS) from non immuno-oncology (IO) assets. Newsflow for IO assets will significantly accelerate as of end 2016 with multiple read outs for durvalumab and/or tremelimumab in lung and head & neck cancers notably.

BE

10% P/E discount to peers does not reflect LT growth prospects.
AstraZeneca trades at a discount despite similar 3yr CAGR (10% 16-19e), though heavily skewed towards out years as FY16 & 17 face major patents expiries. We increase sales 2-8% (higher pipeline, inclusion of the ZS deal) and EPS 3-4% (higher R&D/SG&A partly offset by higher core OOI) which combined with roll over of our DCF and updated comps drive new £53 PT.
Where do we differ from consensus? We now stand 5-9% above 2016-20 consensus earnings, half of this is due to higher revenues (ZS deal, higher ext. revenues) half to higher operating leverage.
Where could we be wrong? Pipeline failure, lack of competitive edge ( IO), inability to protect margins and further pressure on growth platforms.

BE

Thoughts from SHPG on Baxalta and M&A more broadly. Management seemed to
suggest that it is increasingly price sensitive with respect to its pursuit of Baxalta.
That said, we would not necessarily conclude that this commentary is a reflection of
cautious thinking on the part of SHPG regarding BXLT’s hemophilia franchise (on
the contrary, SHPG made it clear that it believes that this franchise is durable, and
could even see its footprint expand, citing a number of gene therapy opportunities
that BXLT has in earlier-stage development). That said, SHPG unquestionably has
the bandwidth to pursue significant M&A in parallel to its quest for BXLT (i.e.,
management does not see real opportunity costs, at least for now, associated with
continued pursuit).

MONY announced last night that founder/non-exec Simon Nixon plans to sell 30m to 35m
shares, halving his holding of 69.8m/12.8%. This is the third block placing this year by a major stakeholder in MONY - Nixon sold 20m shares in May, while Martin Lewis/Trust sold 13.3m in July. Nixon is now subject to a lock-in up to MONY's FY15 results (likely first week of March), but there will be an expectation that he will exit entirely next year. Shares have been strong performers, up 40% YTD. Trading on FY16 PER of 22.3x and 15.0x EV/Ebitda, which looks high enough, given moderating growth rates in FY16/17.

Zoopla Property Group PLC (ZPLA:LSE): Last: 231.62, down 7.18 (-3.01%), High: 247.30, Low: 227.43, Volume: 471.54k
11:41 am
BE

Let me get Morgan Stanley to summarise.

BE

Zoopla reports results in-line with expectations . The company had
already guided for revenue of £107m and EBITDA of £48m and reports £108m
and £49m. EPS of 8.4p is ahead of our estimate of 7.9p partly driven by lower
interest and tax. Exceptionals are a high £12.1m largely driven by the uSwitch
acquisition and we already incorporated them in our forecasts. The final
dividend of 2.5p is broadly in-line with our expectation of 2.7p and implies a
total dividend of 3.5p.
Divisional breakdown as expected. Property services revenue of £80m and
EBITDA of £41m is in-line with our expectation of £81m and £41m,
respectively. Comparison services revenue of £28m (MSe £26m) and EBITDA
of £8m (MSe £7m) is a touch ahead. uSwitch has been fully consolidated since
the beginning of June.

BE

(@fjp73: as you know, OnTheMarket has caused considerable churn in the Zoopla agency list. The net total may not be that meaningful right now, providing you assume that churn is short term.)

11:43 am
BE

(@fjp73: and apologies for sounding like an analyst there.)

BE

Positive outlook with management comfortable with market
expectations for 2016. The company says that it has seen further growth in
membership numbers in the Property Services division since the end of the
Period, although it doesn't disclose the number. It says it is confident of
delivering further membership and ARPA growth. Switching volumes within
the Comparison Services division have continued to be strong since the end of
the Period, especially in Energy where its recent collective switch saw record
levels of consumer participation. The big focus for next year will be on the
integration of the uSwitch and Zoopla offers. Thomson Reuters consensus
shows revenue of £169m and EBITDA of £65m, and we are in-line with
consensus.

BE

KPIs:
- The company had already reported UK agents of 12,702 at the end of
September and says it has continued to grow its membership since then. For
next year we forecast 13,337 UK agents at September 2016.
- UK agent ARPA was +11% in FY15, in-line with our forecast, implying H2
ARPA was +8% reflecting the impact from the OTM launch in February. We
forecast UK agent ARPA growth of 5% in FY16.
- Leads were -14% at 25.2m, reflecting the decline in members since the OTM
launch in February.
- uSwitch reports 9.0m leads in the 4 months it was consolidated, +45% yoy.
ARPL of £3.08 is -8% yoy.

11:43 am
BE

Zoopla is trading on 17x 2016e EV/EBITDA and 21.1x P/E. A blend of
Rightmove and Moneysupermarket would imply an EV/EBITDA multiple of
20.8x and P/E of 27x, implying a discount of c.20%.

BE

Jefferies also positive.

BE

Very.

11:44 am
BE

Zoopla delivered FY2015 results a touch ahead of our expectations this
morning, generating £48.7m of EBITDA against our estimate of £48.0m. In
our view, the angels are in the details; the group has done more with less &
simultaneous stuck to its strategy (cutting marketing costs) and raised its game
with more visitors despite fewer listings, a strong performance in the face of
disruptive headwinds. Zoopla remains our highest conviction Buy across our
coverage.
Investment Thesis. Zoopla is leading rather than following the market as it seeks to be
the 'one-stop shop' for the homebuyer, the Amazon of UK residential, with services ranging
across property to tradesmen to utilities. In our view, two catalysts are likely to lead to
a material re-rating of Zoopla's shares in the coming months: challenger portal 'On The
Market' failing to live up to its own hype of being the UK's number two portal by January
2016, leading to customers returning to Zoopla, and uSwitch continuing to perform ahead
of expectations. Our PT of 400p appears somewhat academic at present, but underlines our
conviction in the attraction of Zoopla's shares.

BE

On the Market on the shelf. We did not see an OTM Black Friday sale and, in our view,
unless estate agents start to fill their Christmas stockings with OTM subscriptions, we doubt
it will be the UK's number two property portal by January 2016. If this target is not met, we
suspect the rate of customers returning to Zoopla will gain momentum.
Governments support for switching services. Yesterday, HM Treasury published 'A
better deal: boosting competition to bring down bills for families and firms', which states
that 'Many households could save up to £390 a year by switching their energy supplier,
current account and mobile tariff' and that 'Consumers should be free to switch services
quickly and easily'.
Growth already anticipated in 2016. Our FY2016 estimates factor in just over 30%
growth in EBITDA and we are leaving these estimates unchanged at this time.
Valuation/Risks
Valuation: At 239p, Zoopla trades on a CY2016E PER of 18.3x and EV/EBITDA of 16.1x. Our
PT of 400p is based on DCF valuation weighted 50% to our Neutral Case, 40% to our Bull
Case and 10% to our Downside Case.
Risks: The key risks to our estimates are the threat of challenger portal OTM, integration
risks relating to the uSwitch acquisition and a downturn in the UK housing market leading to
a material reduction in the number of estate agency branches and new-build developments.

BE

A Black Friday sale for houses would be ......... something.

11:45 am
BE

Probably not a welcome something. But, something.

BE

BE

Down. Anglo down most.

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 398.80, down 7.5 (-1.85%), High: 408.35, Low: 391.55, Volume: 3.35m
11:50 am
BE

It needs a rights issue.

BE

According to UBS, not me.

PM

goodness, below four quid

11:51 am
BE

Divi cut's not enough. Disposals can only do so much. If Anglo doesn't want to be junked, shareholders are on the hook for at least $3bn.

BE

That's the argument. And here it is in summary form.

PM

$3bn?

11:52 am
PM

1-for-3, painful

BE

Yep. At least.

BE

We initiate coverage on Anglo with a Neutral rating
While we like a lot of the things Anglo is doing under CEO Mark Cutifani, ongoing
weakness in the commodity and equity markets (for miners) seems overwhelming:
Costs have been cut, but not enough; operations have improved, but are still not stable
(KIO); assets have been sold, but more cash may be needed; De Beers is a differentiator,
but the diamond market is unexpectedly weak. The longer-term value in Anglo seems
clear, but we think the risks to earnings and balance sheet (at least the credit rating)
appear high in the near term.

11:52 am
BE

Diamonds a disappointing differentiator
Diamonds are and will likely continue to be c50% of Anglo's positive earnings
contributors and the investment case for Anglo lies in its exposure to the consumer part
of the cycle, as opposed to the industrial/infrastructure part. This is, however, not
currently playing out, with polished diamond demand being weak, prices falling and De
Beers rough diamond sales revenue potentially down 44% y-o-y in FY15E and 22%
below our forecast. A flow-through of this weakness into FY16E could see Anglo's
already record-low forecast earnings (US$0.29/sh) under even more pressure (-10-
15%).

BE

Rights issue a real possibility – notwithstanding the reasonable balance sheet
Although on our base-case assumptions, Anglo's balance sheet is in good shape, at
spot prices, the key risk we see for Anglo is a potential credit rating downgrade to non-
investment grade level by S&P (FFO/ND less than 25%), and hence we think Anglo may need to
raise US$3-5bn in cash. Although US$2bn could come from further asset disposals and
a streaming transaction, the balance would probably need to come from a rights issue.

BE

Valuation: Neutral, R100 price target (WACC 10%, 0.5x NPV)
Our PT of R100/sh is at a 50% discount to our R208/sh NPV to take account of Anglo's
very low forecast earnings generation over the next two years, its very high sensitivity to
spot commodity prices and the consequent risk that it may need to raise additional cash
via a rights issue. Catalysts: Anglo is hosting an investor day on 8 December; we
would hope to get an update on production, capex and cost guidance for FY16 as well
as an announcement on a revised dividend policy (which we already model).

11:54 am
BE

Though on the flipside, UBS are also buyers of Glencore.

BE

So we have to question the quality of their work.

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 92.90, down 1.58 (-1.67%), High: 96.97, Low: 92.69, Volume: 17.54m
11:54 am
BE

Here's that one.

BE

Initiating coverage in South Africa with a Buy recommendation
We initiate coverage of Glencore with a Buy recommendation and a R40 price target
which incorporates the risk to Glencore's earnings/valuation from spot prices. Glencore
has very strong earnings growth, driven by good volume growth and a rising basket of
commodity prices. While the company is financially leveraged and could be potentially
vulnerable in a falling commodity price environment, we think the balance sheet is well
structured and management has moved quickly to address gearing/credit rating
concerns.

BE

Balance sheet already looks better, with more liquidity to come
At least Glencore (unlike Anglo) has a number of possible levers to pull to reduce debt
by the proposed US$10bn. With the US$2.5bn equity raise to date, a US$2.4bn
dividend cut and a US$0.9bn streaming transaction, we forecast net debt will be down
to the target US$20bn level by end-FY16. At spot prices, debt metrics put Glencore at
risk of a credit rating downgrade, but we estimate it has another US$4-5bn of realistic
debt reduction potential from streaming transactions and asset sales to offset this.
Marketing should sustainably make US$2.7bn EBIT, but US$3.7bn unlikely
Although Glencore had a disappointing H1 in its Marketing business, with EBIT at only
US$2.2bn annualised (due to one-offs), we believe the business – even with reduced
'readily marketable inventories' (RMI) supporting it – can at least make the bottom end
of the US$2.7-3.7bn range sustainably after FY15. While some investors may have
concerns about a lack of visibility into the Marketing businesses, we think any increased
scrutiny directed towards the business on the back of Noble's issues would be
misplaced.

11:54 am
BE

We have a Buy rating on Glencore and expect the share to re-rate over the next 12
months as management over-delivers on its net debt targets, and as copper and zinc
prices pick up. Our target price of R40 is 0.7x NPV, but this incorporates the Industrial
business at 0.5x NPV to cater for earnings/valuation risk at spot and the Marketing
business at a 10x PE. Catalysts: Glencore is hosting an investor update call on 10
December 2015, where we expect an update on the debt-reduction plans, Marketing's
performance and production guidance for FY16.

BE

Anyway -- numbers are good, generally. Here's Goodbody to summarise them.

12:00 pm
BE

Greene King reported H116 results this morning with group revenues of £917.7m
and PBT of £121.3m, representing 49% and 47% yoy growth respectively. This
compares to our expectations for revenues of £893m and PBT of £102.4m.
Operating margin was 19.6%, down 50 bps yoy as there was a higher contribution
from managed pubs and slightly higher costs. Adjusted basic EPS was 34.5p,
+15.4% yoy. The interim dividend was 8.45p, +6.3% yoy.

BE

The Retail division delivered revenues of £740.2m, +59% yoy growth which was
primarily driven by the Spirit acquisition. Excluding Spirit, Retail grew revenues by
6.7%. In H1, lfl sales grew by 2% versus our expectations for +1.5%, with lfls in
the last 6 weeks of the period up 4.3%, aided by the Rugby World Cup. Spirit retail
LFL sales for H1 were +1.2%. In H1, there were 10 new pub openings and 13 pub
disposals (including 10 required by CMA). Management noted that since the period
end it has seen broadly similar trading patterns across all divisions.

BE

The Pub Partners division reported H1 revenues of £82.1m, +41% yoy growth. In
H1, lfl sales grew by 2.4% with Spirit leased pubs +1.4%. Management continued
to dispose of leased pubs with 15 disposals (incl. 6 required by CMA).

12:00 pm
BE

The Brewing and Brands division reported revenues of £95.4m, +4.7% yoy. Own
brewed volumes grew 3.6% yoy (including the additional volumes to Spirit pubs).
Operating profit came in at £14.5m, +5.1% yoy with management attributing the
margin benefit to channel mix and cost efficiencies in H215.

BE

Management noted that the Spirit integration is proceeding well and is ahead of
plan. In H1, the tenanted and leased pubs were fully integrated into the group.
Management have revised its initial cost synergies target of “at least” £30m up to
£35m with £12m in FY16 and also highlighted the potential for additional revenue
benefits. Management has stated that it will invest an incremental £40-50m in
brands and format optimisation over a 3 year period commencing 2016/17.

BE

Greene King’s results for H1 were impressive and we expect to see upward bias to
forecasts. In relation to the National Living Wage impact, management stated that
it believes that it will be able to mitigate most of the impact focussing on labour
scheduling. Management guidance is for incremental cost £2m in FY17 and £6m in
FY18. We maintain our positive view and re-iterate our BUY recommendation.

12:01 pm
BE

And for the record, I quite like Greene King pubs. No matter where they wash their potatoes.
